Post Text: An accomplished executive aiming to “right size” their career portfolio asks me about how to manage too many commitments. My advice in this week's Dear Founder:

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: The best companies support employee career growth by continuing to do what they’re doing—being successful. Success begets success. If a company isn’t growing, opportunities are more limited for the people who work there. When I started as a director on the Salesforce board in 2006 there were 2,500 employees. Now, there are more than 70,000. This kind of growth has given a lot of people a lot of opportunity.But this isn’t just a numbers game. Great companies make sure that their employees feel valued. They give people new assignments that build their capabilities and expertise. The best companies are always investing in training, paying for classes and seminars, and offering “extra credit” assignments. They make employee growth a priority and they walk the talk. They promote from within when they can, and help people achieve their full potential.#LinkedInTopCompanies

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: Congrats to all the recent graduates! Many will be starting new jobs in the coming weeks; others might still be searching. While the headlines point to a bleak job outlook, this is still an exciting time to enter the workforce. And when it comes to new advances like AI, your generation is the one who gets it the most. You are not bound by the old rules. At the same time, there are some timeless learnings that stay the same. Some career advice as you start this new chapter: Focus on being voted on the team every day. Make sure you do something every day to show others you deserve to be part of their team. It’s all about integrity. Do what you say. Say what you do. Always act in a way that makes people remember you positively. Have a great attitude. We all know cranky people. You might be brilliant, but if you are hard to manage it’s simple to find someone else. Be fun and easy to work with. Work for a higher purpose. You will find more meaning in what you do every day, and it will drive you through the inevitable tough days. Pick your battles. There are a million things to be upset about in any work situation. Only fight about things that are important. Don’t get distracted by noise. Only worry about what you’re doing. It’s hard to run up the stairs as fast as you can when you are looking to the side or at the hundred people behind you trying to catch up.  Don’t be afraid of change. As you advance, don’t look back and wish for things to be the way they used to be. You always want to be growing. Step up to challenges, always volunteering, “I can do that.” Have a higher opinion of yourself and live up to your view of yourself—not what others think of you. Don’t confuse action for traction. Focus on outcomes. Have a talk with your boss. Ask, “What does success look like in 30 days, in 90 days.” Also ask, “What does great look like?”  Focus on expanding your sphere of influence. Don’t get upset about things over which you have no control. If you, invest your energy instead into expanding your sphere of influence, you can make a dramatic impact over more zones. Take time to sit back and reflect on where you are and where you want to be. Make time for a ‘compass check’— it is so easy to fall into a routine and not take the time to see if you are heading where you want to go.  Be a breakout. Most things worth doing are hard. Successful people get to where they are in their careers because they make the hard easy. Be especially brave and bold right now in this crazy economic time. Out of the craziest times come the world’s best innovations. Have fun. I didn’t focus on that enough early in my career. Figure out what you aspire to do and go for it with gusto. P.S. If you are still looking for a job, check out the open position at the Webb Investment Network’s portfolio companies! https://lnkd.in/gvGCwwp5 #GetStarted

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A tech employee, recently laid off, asks if there are still opportunities in tech or if they should consider moving to a different industry.

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: What it takes to start a business in today’s economy is the same as any economy. We’re focusing a lot on #resilience, but it really comes down to #adaptability. External and internal factors are always in flux and therefore great companies are always changing. In the early days, leaders must be judicious about the use of cash, they have to test their way to product market fit. Once they turn on the jets, they have to hire feet on the street. There’s so much that changes as a startup grows from having a product in one country to one that’s sold globally, or as a company scales from three to 3,000 people. This is the natural cycle of building a business that demands constant evolution. Then there are external factors and black swan events—which are unpredictable and outside of anyone’s control—that demand further adaptability. All of this requires having a calm hand at the tiller. The best leaders have very good judgement and can pivot when necessary. Leading a company in any time demands a unique combination of arrogance required to build something out of nothing, and humility necessary to listen to customers and the market. Leading successfully comes down to having a strong value system where there’s great clarity on what you are trying to build and how you will get there.  What do you think are the most important skills for founders?#LinkedInTopStartupsPhoto by Håkon Grimstad on Unsplash

Post Text: An aspiring entrepreneur reaches out and tells me: “I’m in a corporate job, which is going ok, but I don’t love working for someone else. I’m wondering if I should go out on my own.”

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A CEO tells me, “My startup is experiencing a cash crunch.” And asks, “What are my options to keep it afloat?”

Post Text: A new manager has people constantly asking for direction.

Post Text: Exciting news from Webb Investment Network portfolio company Pictorus. Congrats Chris Sullivan and Dillon McEwan!

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A board member tells me that two cofounders are not getting along. It might be tearing the startup apart.

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A worried employee tells me that they’ve been involved in a romantic relationship with a co-worker for more than a year. They’ve kept it from their boss, whom they both directly report to, because he doesn’t condone interoffice relationships. Now that it’s getting more serious, it’s getting uncomfortable living with a secret. “I want to be honest, but I don’t want to lose my job,” they told me.

Post Text: Very exciting news for Webb Investment Network portfolio company Aisera! #Congrats!

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A mid-level manager reaches out to me upset about their company’s return to work plan. Like many employees, they don’t want to go back.

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A consultant asks about what to look for when interviewing board candidates.

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: Very excited to see Superorganism--the first venture capital fund for #biodiversity--come out of stealth.  Congrats Kevin Webb and Tom Quigley, pioneers in the biodiversity venture capital space. I've been inspired by seeing them turn a bold idea into reality and I'm thrilled to see the impact of their portfolio companies. I'm also very #proud.

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: An executive leaving an operating role still wants to make a meaningful impact and asks me how to decide what to pursue next.

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: The CEO of a successful privately-held company confides in me: "Things are not going as expected."

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A CEO tells me that employees and board members have close relationships and has been advised by others that this is risky and that it is necessary to “control the communication.”

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: Congrats to Apple device management and security platform, Kandji, a Webb Investment Network portfolio company, which has been included in the 2023 Forbes Next Billion-Dollar Startup List! This list seeks to identify the top 25 next-generation tech companies most likely to achieve unicorn status. We're energized to see where innovation and growth will take them next. https://lnkd.in/dqhcb5dT #innovation #tech #startup

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: Even in times of economic turbulence, there can be many rewarding opportunities. There’s a lot of work that has to be done. Find a way to take on new initiatives that are important and find a way to help make things better. This will enhance your skills and reputation—and may lead to great things ahead. And, as sad as it is that stocks are off their all-times highs, this also means that new stock grants have a lot more potential. #getahead

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A board member tells me about a startup that is doing well but not ready to go public. They hired a CEO who has done a good job. Now, his options are running out.

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: A founder of a growing startup writes to me with this doozy: “We just completed our Series A financing. Our board is now made up of two cofounders and the lead Series A investor. One of our minor investors asked for an observer seat. I would like for them to participate in board meetings and think they can add value, but I don't want to commit to a perpetual observer seat—especially because I don't want to offer the same role to the other investors who have a larger position in the company.”

Author: Maynard Webb
Post Text: Big news at Sunshine with the launch of Shine, which they've been working on since last summer. Shine is a mobile app focused on easy, intuitive group photo sharing and a website for events with visually stunning invites, fast/fluid communications, and built-in photo sharing.

Post Text: Recently, on #DearFounder, I heard from an investor in a friends and family round who was asked to give money again--at a time when the company isn't doing as well as expected.
